results.headline: Recalling Velvet, Pretzels and Beer, She’s Still Here
results.summary_short: There is no one quite like Elaine Stritch, who is captured in a film biography as she prepares a cabaret show of Sondheim songs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me

results.headline: Kurdish Travels With the Tramp
results.summary_short: In “Chaplin of the Mountains,” two Americans hoping to show silent films to Iraqi Kurds meet a couple of young Kurdish women who have agendas of their own.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chaplin of the Mountains

results.headline: For a Kurdish Woman, No Way Out
results.summary_short: In “One Candle, Two Candles ...,” the heroine is pressured to marry a rich older man.

results.headline: From Zola, With Blood, Lust and Bloodlust
results.summary_short: “In Secret” is the latest adaptation of Émile Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin.”

results.headline: Lava and Lust
results.summary_short: In Paul W. S. Anderson’s gladiator disaster film “Pompeii,” the lone survivor of a Celtic tribe becomes a slave, but his horse-whisperer talents helps redirect his fate.

results.headline: Treachery Thrives Where Trust Withers
results.summary_short: The title character of “Omar” is a sensitive young Palestinian who believes a happy ending can spring from the despair of his homeland.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Omar

results.headline: Celebrating Bondage Over Bonds of Marriage
results.summary_short: In the Bollywood movie “Highway,” a woman suffocated by her coming wedding finds escape in her kidnapping and love with her abductor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Highway

results.headline: A Trail of Tears and Corpses
results.summary_short: As the prime suspect in a cocaine heist, a retired gangster with a gap in his memory seems to be on everyone’s to-do list.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Out

results.headline: A Pretty Mental Patient Comes Home to Meet the Folks
results.summary_short: “Barefoot” stars Evan Rachel Wood as a young woman with a bit of psychosis but who is charming nonetheless.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Barefoot

results.headline: A Drive-In Flickers to Life for a Teenager
results.summary_short: Alicia Silverstone seeks a man as salvation, while her teenage daughter, played by A J Michalka, talks to an imaginary friend.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angels In Stardust

results.headline: Down and Armed in Paris, Teenager in Tow
results.summary_short: In “3 Days to Kill,” Kevin Costner plays a much-put-upon C.I.A. assassin in Paris with bad guys to dispatch and child-care issues.

results.headline: A Frustrated Woman on the Verge of More of the Same
results.summary_short: “Child’s Pose,” by Calin Peter Netzer, is a family drama set in the new Romania.

results.headline: Bandit Buddies Separated by a Woman
results.summary_short: Boyhood friends who become bandit kings are put to the test by a beautiful woman in “Gunday,” a Bollywood film set in the 1970s.

results.headline: Shedding the Cliché of High School Sex
results.summary_short: “Date and Switch,” directed by Chris Nelson, is a new entry in the high school movie pool.

results.headline: Demons at Work in Snowy Magic of New York
results.summary_short: The film adaptation of “Winter’s Tale” partakes of wide-eyed mystical wonder but pitches helplessly into ridiculousness.

results.headline: Fantasy Girl at Your Service
results.summary_short: In “Lucky Bastard,” a contest in which the winner is invited to have sex with an actress from a pornographic film has grim consequences.

results.headline: Therapist and Patient, Odd and Charming
results.summary_short: “Jimmy P.” unconventionally tells the story of a troubled American Indian and war veteran and the psychoanalyst who tries to unlock the secrets of his personality.

results.headline: Once a Lowlife, Always a Lowlife
results.summary_short: In “Easy Money: Hard to Kill,” the second film of a Swedish franchise, a former glamour boy escapes from prison and tries unsuccessfully to eke an honest existence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Easy Money: Hard to Kill

results.headline: A Couplet Fantasy Denied
results.summary_short: In “Adult World,” an aspiring 22-year-old poet takes the only job she can find, as an assistant in a pornographic bookstore, but persists in a fantasy about literary renown.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adult World

results.headline: With a Dentist’s Chair and a Chicken Mask, a Girl Can’t Say No
results.summary_short: “About Last Night,” a raucously entertaining remake, follows the difficulties faced by two couples, one sensitive and well behaved, the other outrageously naughty.
